Morality`

public, informal, rational, impartial```

`system of rules for guiding humanity

`system of principles for evaluating those rules

`purpose-prevent or alleviate harm and suffering


Normative

the way people should be based on morality

Descriptive

the way people are (facts) based on sociology, psychology


cultural relativism-different cultures

moral relativism - we shoul

moral absolutism - only one correct answer

ethical objectivism - a purality of plausible answers as long as rational criteria are met


Ethics`

study of moral issues


Ethical Theories

`internally

`comprehensive

`systematic


Consequence Based

primary goal- produce desirable outcome for moral agents (utilitarianism)

we want be happy


Duty Based

immanual kant

goal-morality is grounded in moral agents obligations to one another (deontology)

categorical imperative-always act on the rule that you could wish it could become universal law

we can't make a desision to kill people


Character Based

goal-morality is grounded in virtues (Aristolian)

virtue-honesty,fair,compasionate,wise,modest
CS 210.Lecture 2:
$0#

CyberEthics

(James Moor)

cyber technology is logically malleable

Policy Vacuum

`our technology is being developed so fast, we can't make policies fast enough

Conceptual muddles- is a phone a computer

Disclosive model - (philip brey)

some of the features of our technolog is morrally opaque

you can crerate anything and you will run into moral issues

morally opaque - we don't understand all of the outcomes of our technology

Disclosive method -

Tavani's Method```

`Identify the feature

``disclose morall opaque featrues

``assess sociological implications

``search for existing policies or ethical codes

`Analyze th ethical issue

``identify any policy vaccums

``clear p conceptual muddles

`Deliberate on ethical issue

``apply one or more ethical theories

``justify the position using logical arguments

Logical Argumentaion

meathod used to test an ethical thesis

claim - a statement or assertion

argument - a series of claims aimed at finding truth on a claim

Valid Argument```

if we accept the premises, i is impossible for the conclusion to be false

Sound Argument ```

strong and convincing argument

Inductive Argument```

an invalid argument can be convincing

Fallacious Argument```

invalid arguments whose premise do not support conclusion

Logical Fallacy

Non Sequitur ```

the conclusion does not follow the premise

doensn't follow

Asumming the Concequent```

reversing the direction of an implication

if p then q. Q is true

Appeal to X```

if X is popular, tradition, authority, threat, novel

appeaing to emtion not information

Ad Hominem```

attacking person and not the argument

"character assassination"

Complex Question```

sneak a premise into a question

how often do you beat your wife

Tu Quoque```

dismising a moral argument by pointing out hypocrisy

two wrongs make a right

Naturalistic Fallacy```

inferring ought from is

trating a normative as fact

"if I don't steal this laptop, then someone else will, so its fine"

False Dilemma```

only give limited choices when there are more

''if your not my friend your my enimy'

Begging the Question```

assuming he conclusion in your argument

"circular reasoning"
CS 210.Logical Fallacies:
$1#

Fallacious Argument

        invalid arguments whose premise do not support conclusion

     Logical Fallacy

        Non Sequitur

               the conclusion does not follow the premise

               doensn't follow

        Asumming the Concequent

               reversing the direction of an implication

               if p then q. Q is true

        Appeal to X

               if X is popular, tradition, authority, threat, novel

               appeaing to emtion not information

               9 out of 10 doctors agree that this soda is delisious

        Ad Hominem

               attacking person and not the argument

               "character assassination"

        Complex Question

               sneak a premise into a question

               how often do you beat your wife

        Tu Quoque

               dismising a moral argument by pointing out hypocrisy

               two wrongs make a right

        Naturalistic Fallacy

               inferring ought from is

               trating a normative as fact

               "if I don't steal this laptop, then someone else will, so its fine"

        False Dilemma

               only give limited choices when there are more

               ''if your not my friend your my enimy'

        Begging the Question

               assuming he conclusion in your argument

               "circular reasoning"

        Equivocation

               using ambiguity of meaning to mislead in an argument

               changing meaning ( right -> correct)

               "I have a right to make money therefore making money is right"

        Argument to Moderation

               assuming the middle ground is correct when it may not

               "some people believe vaccine are bad so we must use less vaccine (0.5)"

        Special Pleading

               holding standards to only certain people

        False Analogy

               assuming things that are similar must be similar to others

               "an mp3 is like a physical album, so getting a copy without paying is theft"

               "all coffee addicts should be arrested"

        Straw Man Argument

               ignoring your opponent's argument and refuting a weaker argument

               "you say we should cut school funding. Why do you hate education"

        Argument from Ignorance

               arguing a claim is true because we can't prove it false

               "we don't know how crop circles are made; therfore, they must be made by

               aliens"

        Post Hoc Ergo Propter Hoc

               assuming causation from a correlation

               "the divorce rate in Maine is correlated with the consumption of margarine;

               therefore, you shouldn't be eating margarine."

        Composition/Division

               arguing that the whole has the attributes of its part

               "this laptop is the best. It has the best processor, ram, and hard drive"

               "i can eat table salt, so it is safe to eat sodium"
